The Future Of Intersession
Most people don't take the three-week
courses offered during Intersession because
they have better things to do.
They ski in Vermont. Swim in Florida.
Visit friends at Penn State. Study for the
MCAT. Get jobs in Manhattan. Drink beer
with high school friends. And sleep a lot.
Most undergraduates want to enjoy
themselves during Intersession. And rightly
so. They have to unwind from the intense
academic atmosphere at Hopkins so they
decide to leave.
They say,"Why should I stay if there are
no god courses to take?" Well, unfortunately, it's the domino effect again. Lack
of interest in previous years has decreased
the present number of courses.
So Intersession has to be popularized.
There is no tuition fee. Professors and

graduate students volunteer their services
and won't teach unless undergraduates show
an interest; a group of undergraduates could
ask either a professor or a graduate student
to teach a certain course.
Undergraduates could also approach a
professor and ask, "Could I do an independent project? This is what I want to do."
Undergraduates, however, aren't the only ones who are responsible. Professors could
also come up with courses—these courses
don't necessarily have to be conventional;
they could be experimental or could concern
topics outside the professor's discipline.
So the possibilities are there. Although the
names of Intersession courses have been submitted to the Registrar, courses can still he
added if students and facility want them to
be added.

Knight's Grenada
To the Editor:
I am a senior at the University. I am writing this letter in

reply to a recent article in the
Friday edition of the Baltimore
Sun. In this article, Frank
Somerville described Professor
Knight's criticism of the Grenada invasion. Knight is an expert
on Caribbean affairs and he has
written an excellent book on
this region's history. Alt hough
his criticism is scholarly and
well-founded, I disagree strongly with many of Professor
Knight's comments.
Sommerville claimed t hat
Knight was being cynical of the
American invasion of Grenada.
The professor attributed the
crisis to another CIA miscalculation. Certainly this rings true
in both the Bay of Pigs fiascc
and in Vietnam, but not Grena
da. In Vietnam, there was a
distinct lack of clear strategic
objectives. American GI's were
hard pressed to distinguish between the enemy and the civilian population. The Marine's
current situation in Lebanon is
in some ways analagous.
But Grenada is neither like
Lebanon or Vietnam. This tiny
island is situated along a vital
supply route used by oil tankers
to reach the United States. The
invasion of Grenada had a clear
strategic objective: to save
American lives and occupy a
hostile airstrip. The Cuban and
Soviet advisors were more like
soldiers than construction
workers. U.S. Army rangers
encountered stiff resistance in
and around the airfield. The
Russian command center and
the cache of arms were in the
President's words, "a military
bastion of export terror and
undermine democracy."
I did not vote for Reagan,
but on the Grenada invasion as
an American I could not agree
more whole-heartedly. It's time
to stop the Russians and
especially the Cubans from
pushing the United States
around. The Grenada invasion
has what the Marines lack in
Lebanon: a clear strategic objective and a justifiable military
purpose. Like Reagan, I admire
the Marines and Rangers who

died this week defending our
freedom and honor.
The issue of the Grenada invasion raises a larger question
at home. The indifference of
many Americans to current
events. Professor Knight's
comments are only possible in
a democray and they are a
tribute to the nation's institutions and government. Anyone
criticizing the government in
Russia or Cuba would most
likely disappear. The Marines
and Rangers in Grenada are
defending vital American
strategic interests and protecting American lives.
Thomas Wills

PSU Responds to Cobb
o the Editor:
We believe that Mr. Cobb's
letter (October 28) has serious
flaws, quite understandable of
course in light of the Republican's record in trumpeting the
"defense of Free World law
and order." Fhis bloody and
shameful record, coupled with
the conceited and chauvinistic
attitude that the U.S. has the
right to do whatever it pleases,
must anger and disgust all those
who have a sense of justice.
About three weeks ago,
President Reagan declared in a
televised statement that "covert
operations are a right" of this
country. Last week, he declared
that invasions are a right of this
country if the U.S. interests are
threatened. Many of us must
wonder if there is any limit to
"U.S. interests" in the world,
just as there seems to be no
limit to "national security matters" within the U.S.!
In any case, Mr. Cobb's letter reflects more ignorance,
dogmatism, and mendacity
than honest representation of
the facts. His arrogant glibness
would indicate that he has
carefully studied Caribbean affairs, as well as being.privy to
information to which the rest of
America had no access. We
would thus like to allow some
pointed facts to deflate this

ideological gas-bag Cobb.
The airport issue seems to be
a favorite topic in the Republican justification of the invasion. Three facts alter radically the picture they have painted
of this much-maligned construction, however:(I)Grenada
first approached not Cuba, not
the USSR, but the United
States with the airport construction project. (2) Grenada was
the last country in the Caribbean to have a 9000 foot runway. Before its construction,
not even commercial jets could
land on the island. (3) The
European Common Market
countries, not Cuba or the
Soviet Union, were the largest
contributors to the airport
construction.
Several other apologies for
interventionism crumble when
faced by facts as well. For example, Reagan cites the presence of Cubans, Soviet diplomats, and a few East European and North Korean technicians as evidence that Grenada
had become a festering hive of
communism, the vanguard of
the Red Tide to drown the "Free
World" (presumably Adams'
Barbados, Siega's .lamaica, and
Charles' Dominica!). But we
should recall that Americans
constituted by far the largest
foreign population on the
island, larger than the Cubans,
Russians and East Europeans
together. And one can make a
much stronger argument that
the American students unwittingly served U.S. conquest,
than that Cuban construction
workers and Bulgarian engineers served to "export revolution and terror".
As for t he safety of these
students, the facts again expose
the hypocrisy of Reagan and his
collegiate disciples: (1) The
Grenadan government had continually assured their safety and
even invited an American
delegation to observe the situation firsthand. Their assurances
were ignored, their invitation
snubbed. (2) Five hundred
parents of the students wrote
President Reagan before the invasion that their children were
safe and asked that he not take
any drastic measures. (3) Four
chartered planes left Grenada
the day- .before the invasion,
carrying foreign nationals who,
•

wanted to leave; more planes
were scheduled for Tuesday.
This invasion is a. flagrant
and premeditated act of military aggression. Since Reagan
took office he has referred to
Grenada as a "threat to the
Western Hemisphere". The
same leaders now hypocritically vaunted as martyrs killed in
"cold blood" by "terrorists"
were themselves once considered dangerous harbingers of

Most people don't take the three-week
courses offered during Intersession because
they have better things to do.

academic atmosphere at Hopkins so they
decide to leave.

no god courses to take?" Well, unfortunately, it's the domino effect again. Lack
of interest in previous years has decreased
the present number of courses.

There is no tuition fee. Professors and

graduate students volunteer their services
and won't teach unless undergraduates show
an interest; a group of undergraduates could
ask either a professor or a graduate student
to teach a certain course.

also come up with courses—these courses
don't necessarily have to be conventional;
they could be experimental or could concern
topics outside the professor's discipline.

names of Intersession courses have been submitted to the Registrar, courses can still he

Knight's Grenada
To the Editor:
I am a senior at the University. I am writing this letter in

reply to a recent article in the
Friday edition of the Baltimore
Sun. In this article, Frank
Somerville described Professor
Knight's criticism of the Grenada invasion. Knight is an expert
on Caribbean affairs and he has
written an excellent book on
this region's history. Alt hough
his criticism is scholarly and
well-founded, I disagree strongly with many of Professor
Knight's comments.
Sommerville claimed t hat
Knight was being cynical of the
American invasion of Grenada.
The professor attributed the
crisis to another CIA miscalculation. Certainly this rings true
in both the Bay of Pigs fiascc
and in Vietnam, but not Grena
da. In Vietnam, there was a
distinct lack of clear strategic
objectives. American GI's were
hard pressed to distinguish between the enemy and the civilian population. The Marine's
current situation in Lebanon is
in some ways analagous.
But Grenada is neither like
Lebanon or Vietnam. This tiny
island is situated along a vital
supply route used by oil tankers
to reach the United States. The
invasion of Grenada had a clear
strategic objective: to save
American lives and occupy a
hostile airstrip. The Cuban and
Soviet advisors were more like
soldiers than construction
workers. U.S. Army rangers
encountered stiff resistance in
and around the airfield. The
Russian command center and
the cache of arms were in the
President's words, "a military
bastion of export terror and
undermine democracy."
I did not vote for Reagan,
but on the Grenada invasion as
an American I could not agree
more whole-heartedly. It's time
to stop the Russians and
especially the Cubans from
pushing the United States
around. The Grenada invasion
has what the Marines lack in
Lebanon: a clear strategic objective and a justifiable military
purpose. Like Reagan, I admire
the Marines and Rangers who

died this week defending our
freedom and honor.
The issue of the Grenada invasion raises a larger question
at home. The indifference of
many Americans to current
events. Professor Knight's
comments are only possible in
a democray and they are a
tribute to the nation's institutions and government. Anyone
criticizing the government in
Russia or Cuba would most
likely disappear. The Marines
and Rangers in Grenada are
defending vital American
strategic interests and protecting American lives.
Thomas Wills

carefree childhood was:
